title: Are gaming PCs good for music production? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not if you’re looking to do multi-track recording directly on it. It’s great for programmed music much but hopeless for recording actual musicians unless you use a separate analogue pre-amp mixer so the musicians aren’t playing on a delay (you would then just have to work out how much to offset your tracks by to put them back in time). Your musicians also need to bring their amps rather than being able to use built in amp simulators and effects. Or you need to buy amps for everything you want to play. You don’t get the option of just plugging straight into the desk. That’s an added expense and increased hassle. If you want decent performance out of it then a PC is not the cheapest option. I have to say I am yet to see a PC which can cope with multitrack recording. Latency latency latency. Avoid PCs like the plague unless you’re really good at playing 60 ms ahead of the music you’re trying to play along with. PCs reward you for playing perfectly in time by playing it back with a nasty delay. Well I can’t compensate for it anyway. I’ve trained myself to play in time. At no point was I deliberately practising how to play two thirds of a sixteenth note out of time with all the other instruments! I just never foresaw a time when I might have needed to be able to do that. Forget the PC and buy a dedicated digital multitrack workstation instead. The latency on those things feels far closer to zero and when you play back what you’ve recorded it matches what you thought you played. It works. If you really have your heart set on using a PC then make sure it’s not a laptop and make sure it’s an i7. Make sure it’s got a proper sound card in it and not just the toy one on the motherboard. Avoid external sound cards as they also add latency. You often have to switch out or completely remove other components which are introducing latency. It’s a bloody nightmare and you have to learn SO much more than you want to just to get the thing half usable (unless you’re very lucky with the PC you buy). Buy a Mac instead. I assume installing Linux might improve matters on a PC but don’t know what decent software might be available for Linux. I basically know nothing about Linux and music. Back to the Mac: I’ve used Garage Band and it’s nowhere near as bad as using a PC - no glitches, less latency. Managed to record a song with my friends and at no point did we have to dig into settings or re-take because there’d been a glitch in the recording halfway through the best take ever. Mac seemed to work ok. I don’t have enough experience with them to say for certain that all Macs will be suitable. I assume you just want to go for the fastest one with the most memory you can afford. I spent £900 on my crappy Acer - it has a single headphone jack input and audio latency of 60 ms. I spent £370 on my Tascam digital multitrack. It has 24-bit audio, 32 tracks, built in effects, XLR connections, phantom power and zero latency as far as is noticeable (it can’t truly be zero as it’s doing analogue to digital and digital to analogue conversions which take a finite amount of time). You can make decent sounding music with that and there’s loads of options. There’s enough inputs to mic up a drum kit if you want for example. It’s got dynamic compression built in for each channel if you want it too. It takes standard jack cables if you don’t have XLR. The computer was a complete waste of money as far as music production goes. Sure, I can use it to mixdown tracks I’ve recorded on my multitrack and it’s great to be able to “see” the music, but my dedicated multitrack (the Tascam) also offers a whole load of mixdown options including multiband dynamic compression and EQ. I don’t need the PC for anything much other than creating mp3s and adding overall flanger/phaser really. I can do everything else in my Tascam and it’s all done by simply moving sliders and turning knobs until it sounds right rather than double-click, type in a number, listen to it back, double-click again, take a guess how much to adjust the number by, listen to it again, double-click the track, take another guess, etc.. PCs suck the humanity out of the music creation process. Tascam used to do a version which had a built in CD burner and the bay is still there so I can probably still add one and then I really wouldn’t have a use for my PC other than typing stuff on Quora. The only criticisms I have of my Tascam is that it only has one headphone socket, there’s a slight delay after recording each track before you can record the next one (I think that’s it writing the track to the memory card - the data on the memory card doesn’t appear to be compressed so I don’t think it’s compression time) and it can’t be synced up with a MIDI device so I have to mixdown my MIDI to an audio and transfer it directly onto one of the Tascam’s tracks. It means I lose one track if I want to be able to hear my MIDI stuff when I record the acoustic instruments and it makes it less than straightforward if I realise I want to change just one note. Otherwise perfect and less than half the price of my PC. I often find that a musical idea pops into my head and I grab my guitar to record it before it fades away. The PC takes longer than normal to boot then installs a Windows update which prevents my DAW from recognising the sound card when it starts up so I have to restart. When I finally get into my DAW I arm a track and record what’s in my head. At this point using the Tascam I would probably disappear into the music for a few hours, refining it, adding bits here, removing bits there, recording snippets of melody which suggest themselves to me and at the end of the night I’d have created a bunch of guitar tracks with loads of material I can build on. If I want to add drums I easily can because I’ve played everything in time with the click (I normally start with the guitars and do the drums second or third depending how important the bassline is). What happens with the PC is I try to record a second track and notice that the click and the first guitar track aren’t in time at all and it’s really distracting. On sustained chords the click draws my ear and I shift into it’s timing then when the riff starts again I am drawn back into synchronisation with that track. Once I add a couple more tracks it just becomes a mess because nothing really knows what it’s trying to be in time with and there isn’t a solid pulse to the music. Trying to add things with very definite and noticeable beat placements such as drums is impossible. I have to play out of time to play in time! Soon enough I get drawn into the menus of the DAW and sound options in control panel trying to do something about the latency. Nothing has any noticeable effect although if I reduce the buffers below 64 samples the sound starts to break up. I can make things worse, but not better. I end up so far down the rabbit hole that I just get angry about the fact I seem to be powerless to fix it and by that point the chance of making any decent music is out the window. I hate my computer. I’ve lost a lot of tunes to it. In my opinion PCs are utterly useless for music recording unless you get really lucky with low latency components. Musically, they’re toys and there’s good reason proper studios don’t just Ebay all their equipment and replace it with a PC or two. The modifications you might have to make to your computer in the pursuit of low latency might even reduce the performance of your games and spoil that for you too. I’ve tried contacting Acer for help and advice - they’re about as much use as a chocolate fireguard. Took them two months just to tell me that they had no solution for me! It’ll work just fine for music production provided you have some other way to make the actual recordings. It’s just not good at realtime stuff. You could actually get away with using a 20 year-old PC with a kick ass sound card in it for music production. I realise I’ve answered this as if it was about music recording. Well, I suppose that is really quite a large part of music production so, although I’m not sure, I think my answer is relevant. Hopefully. Save your money. Whatever PC you already have is probably good enough and spending more might not actually give you all that much more capability. If you’ve got a spare £900 then you could spend ~£400 on a standalone multitrack recorder and keep the rest to upgrade your graphics card when the next must-have graphics card comes out so your games look awesome. That’s a better spend of your money. On an almost completely unrelated note: My Tascam cost me exactly £370 and I ordered it on the 8th of March 2014. At that point I had not turned on my TV or read any news. 370 is significant to that day for a much more widely known reason… When I bought a DVD of Titanic I found out that the receipt showed I’d bought it at 19:12… On the 14th of April… And a music-related joke to end on: I downloaded a pirate copy of Bohemian Rhapsody the other night. Total waste of time. It was shot from the back of a cinema and all I could see was a little silhouetto of a man!

The most taxed computer-part when making music is actually the CPU… which is the second highest on the priority-list for a gaming PC—the highest there is generally the GPU… which does practically nothing for music production. For a PC to be good for music production you generally want it to have 3 things—excluding external things like an audio interface or monitors: A strong CPUA good amount of RAMA lot of redundant storageA gaming PC generally does have a good CPU and an acceptable amount of RAM, so, not really any problems there. Sure, the GPU is basically wasted money for an audio workstation, but you sure could far worse then using a decent gaming rig for such. If you already have a decent* gaming rig and want to make music with your PC as well, you should be perfectly fine to just get an audio interface, some monitors and a DAW and you’ll be good to go—the PC’s hardware should be no hindrance and, in fact, should be plenty strong enough to not run into any serious bottlenecks anytime soon.  *by “decent” I generally mean something like an second generation or newer i5 and 8+ GB of RAM. The graphics card matters not in this case. Just to give a little idea how taxing music can get: my rig has an i7–6700 and 24 gigs of DDR4 RAM… I can max that CPU out if I want—and sometimes do, especially when working on some guitar tone and I get sidetracked again, adding far more then needed—but so far I didn’t manage to max out the RAM—but I do regularly get over 16 gigs and am practically always over 8… though the last thing might just be windows being somewhat inefficient seeing as I currently use 10 1/2 GB according to the task manager and I am doing nothing besides surfing the web and listening some music—and yes, 3 gigs are just used by the browser… I really should close tabs when I don’t need them.

Yes and no. The two machines have different priorities, with some overlap and some divergence. Gaming machines are GPU-focused; but usually lots of horsepower and RAM too, maybe not quite as much focus on the storage. The one thing a gaming PC does that makes it potentially bad as a music production box is make a lot of noise. With all the fans, it introduces too much sound pressure into a room *if* you’re recording with open mics. if you’re all electronic/sequenced, this matters a lot less but can still color your mixes. [[EDIT - new PC specs]]My PC is a music production rig; it’s a Core i7–9770K with 64GB RAM, a 1TB NVME SSD for boot/swap/temp/apps, a 1TB SSD for active recording projects and video rendering target, and 13TB worth of 7200RPM spindles for passive data storage/backup. My sound device is a USB3-connected Presonus Studio18|24, the onboard sound is disabled completely (8 inputs, zero-latency monitoring). Most importantly *it’s in a case designed to be super quiet*; lots of insulative properties, almost no bare sheet metal to resonate, and highly efficient and quiet cooling. It clocks 24db at full utilization. You need lots of CPU in order to run a lot of plugins and virtual instruments simultaneously; you need a lot of RAM to hold a lot of audio files and samples in RAM at the same time, and you need fast storage to tolerate high bandwidth writes from multiple tracks at the same time. My graphics card is paltry by gaming standards (onboard Intel, using that because Adobe AfterEffects can utilize the GPU for rendering) because as has been said elsewhere, 3D graphics performance is essentially moot in a music production environment. and “gaming” for me is Spider Solitaire. ;) The audio and video monitors are a whole different discussion; and outside the scope of your question. Hope that helps.

Absolutely! Everything that a great gaming PC consists of will be useful for a great Music production PC, except for the graphic card. Yup, you do not require a heavy duty graphic card for your music production, even if you make music for videos! A word of advice though, if you can afford go for an i7 rather than an i5! Unlike a gaming rig, which relies on the graphic card for all the juice, a music production relies on the cpu for all its juice! All the sample libraries, plugins and vst instruments rely on the cpu for smooth functioning! So get the best cpu you can afford. A gaming PC will make do with an i5 and an awesome Graphic Card, Music production will benefit more with an awesome CPU! Also make sure you have a separate hard drive(minimum 7200 rpm) for your OS, one for all your projects and one external drive for your sample libraries, loops, instruments, etc. It's not an absolute requirement, but having separate hard drives will definitely help in system performance. A slow hard drive will bogg down performance no matter how fast your processor is. Get 2 identical Ram sticks of your choice. The new Skylake processors support upto 2400 mhz of ram speed at stock speeds. So basically get the fastest ram that you can afford. Overclocking : A lot of Gaming rigs are overclocked! It's a privilege for PC owners. Get a k version of Intel processor, if you want to overclock. Though overclocking is not an absolute necessity, so it's all up to choice. Goodluck!

Absolutely, depending on certain aspects of your gaming PC. Gaming PCs typically have high-performance components. Most money is spent on the GPU — the graphics card, which has very limited effect on performance for audio production. But sometimes, gamers spend less on the CPU, opting for just an i5-series CPU. For music production, i7 and i9 CPUs are preferred. Now if you spent for a premium gaming computer, you may have opted for a better i7 or i9, so you’re in good shape. Assuming you have at least an i7, the next issue is storage. You want to add a dedicated drive (SSD or 7200rpm HD) for your audio recording. You don’t want to record directly onto the boot volume where the OS and your installed applications live. One area where gaming PCs save money is on their cooling fans… i.e. they don’t worry too much about noise, because most gamers are wearing headsets and don’t really notice the noise. But if you’re doing studio-type work, you might want to replace your gaming PC’s fans with more premium, silent-type fans from companies like Noctua and BeQuiet! so that the ambient noise level from the computer is greatly reduced. So yes… gaming PCs can be great for this purpose, but you might need an upgrade here or there.

Yes. As gaming computers usually have higher-end internal systems, installing and using a DAW (Digital Audio Workstation) should be a smooth process. However, the opposite can’t be said - I make music using Ableton Live on my laptop but I have tried to play games on it as well and that’s a no-no: I need more space, a better soundcard, and better graphics, which means I’d have to get a new computer to play games. But when running a DAW, all that really matters is that you have enough space to install it (and it’s usually smaller in size than GTA V, for example), and a good soundcard (which most gaming computers have).

If horsepower is all you care about, than a powerful gaming pc will most likely be able to handle all the music production software that you want to run. However, gaming PCs are usually optimized for a heavy graphics workload. They can get away with having a less powerful processor, in favor of having a really powerful graphics card. For music production, the CPU probably matters more than the GPU. You may also need to buy additional parts like a sound card to get better audio output!

Graphics performance typically won’t make a difference, but a fast processor, lots of RAM and a fast disk (mechanical or SSD) will help whether you’re producing music or gaming. I personally use Macs for music production; I’ve been using them for years for stability reasons, but these days, a properly configured and maintained system running Windows 10 can be expected to be just as stable. (I do have a gaming rig running Windows 10.) At the end of the day it’s as much personal preference as anything else.
